page.title: Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian revolution under Supreme Council of the Armed Forces

rev.diff:
Line 124: Line 124:
Several stages had been set up by the [[Coalition of the Youth of the Revolution|Revolution Youth Coalition]] (a coalition of liberal parties and movements), the Muslim Brotherhood, the Wafd party and leftist parties in order to organise the protests. As the Muslim Brotherhoodâs stage was the highest and largest, many protesters complained that they were attempting to gain an unfair advantage over the other political parties. These accusations were in addition to the Muslim Brotherhood's opposition to a sit-in called by other political groups to pressure the Supreme Council of Armed Forces into meeting their demands. Though the Muslim Brotherhood decided to join the protests only two days before the event, it said that it would avoid the sit-in and leave by 17:00. The event was used to rally support for the various groups by organizing their own tents and passing out paraphernalia.<ref name="englishahram">{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/15899/Egypt/Politics-/Hundreds-of-thousands-revitalise-Egypts-revolution.aspx |title=Hundreds of thousands revitalise Egypt's revolution on Determination Friday â Politics â Egypt â Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |accessdate=10 July 2011}}</ref>
Several stages had been set up by the [[Coalition of the Youth of the Revolution|Revolution Youth Coalition]] (a coalition of liberal parties and movements), the Muslim Brotherhood, the Wafd party and leftist parties in order to organise the protests. As the Muslim Brotherhoodâs stage was the highest and largest, many protesters complained that they were attempting to gain an unfair advantage over the other political parties. These accusations were in addition to the Muslim Brotherhood's opposition to a sit-in called by other political groups to pressure the Supreme Council of Armed Forces into meeting their demands. Though the Muslim Brotherhood decided to join the protests only two days before the event, it said that it would avoid the sit-in and leave by 17:00. The event was used to rally support for the various groups by organizing their own tents and passing out paraphernalia.<ref name="englishahram">{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/15899/Egypt/Politics-/Hundreds-of-thousands-revitalise-Egypts-revolution.aspx |title=Hundreds of thousands revitalise Egypt's revolution on Determination Friday â Politics â Egypt â Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |accessdate=10 July 2011}}</ref>
â
The next day, the Minister of Interior [[Mansour Essawy]] sacked the head of the Suez Security Police Osama El-Taweel and appointed Adel Abd El-Hamid as his replacement following clashes between families of those killed during the revolution and the Suez police. The clashes, in turn, followed accusations that the head of the Suez police had helped the police officers accused of killing protesters to escape trial after a court ruling released the officers on bail.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/15974/Egypt/Politics-/Egyptian-interior-minister-replaces-Suez-police-ch.aspx |title=Egyptian interior minister replaces Suez police chief â Politics â Egypt â Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |accessdate=10 July 2011}}</ref> Prime Minister Essam Sharaf also responded to the protests, saying that any member of the security forces who was accused of killing protesters would be sacked: "I have issued new instructions as a matter of urgency for the minister of interior to suspend any officers implicated in the killing of protesters. I have also demanded a swift return to the highest levels of security on the streets of Egypt to make them safe again and give our citizens the dignity they deserve."<ref name="aljaz">{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/07/201179202618591744.html |title=Egypt PM vows to sack murder-accused police â Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |accessdate=10 July 2011}}</ref>
+
On 9 July, the Minister of Interior [[Mansour Essawy]] sacked the head of the Suez Security Police Osama El-Taweel and appointed Adel Abd El-Hamid as his replacement following clashes between families of those killed during the revolution and the Suez police. The clashes, in turn, followed accusations that the head of the Suez police had helped the police officers accused of killing protesters to escape trial after a court ruling released the officers on bail.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/15974/Egypt/Politics-/Egyptian-interior-minister-replaces-Suez-police-ch.aspx |title=Egyptian interior minister replaces Suez police chief â Politics â Egypt â Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |accessdate=10 July 2011}}</ref> Prime Minister Essam Sharaf also responded to the protests, saying that any member of the security forces who was accused of killing protesters would be sacked: "I have issued new instructions as a matter of urgency for the minister of interior to suspend any officers implicated in the killing of protesters. I have also demanded a swift return to the highest levels of security on the streets of Egypt to make them safe again and give our citizens the dignity they deserve."<ref name="aljaz">{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/07/201179202618591744.html |title=Egypt PM vows to sack murder-accused police â Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |accessdate=10 July 2011}}</ref>
